intro: Macroclinidium verticillatum, commonly known as the spiral cactus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of South America. It is characterized by its compact, globular stem covered in dense, white spines that provide protection from herbivores and excessive sunlight. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish flowers that bloom during the rainy season, attracting pollinators such as bees and moths. Its leaves are reduced to spines, and it stores water in its fleshy stems, adapting to its harsh environment. The plant's unique spiral arrangement of spines is a distinguishing feature in its morphology.
